channel.title: Health News | Mail Online
channel.description: Check out the latest health news, articles, advice, and trends for you and your family on topics like nutrition, weight loss, popular diets, and exercise.

item.title: Craving junk on a diet? Go a run: Study finds strenuous exercise makes you less likely to cave
item.description: A study by Washington State University has found rats subjected to an intense exercise regime were better able to resist cravings for fatty food and it could have implications for human dieters.

item.title: UK records fewer than 20k daily cases for second day in a row and 284 deaths
item.description: UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) bosses posted another 19,795 cases to the Covid dashboard over the last 24 hours.

item.title: At least 70% of people have had Covid in England, official data shows
item.description: The Office for National Statistics estimates that 38.5million people got infected at some point in England between April 2020 and February 2022, the equivalent of 70.7 per cent.

item.title: Ice creams made by Oreo and Biscoff can have as much salt as McDonald's fries
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: This website analysed the nutritional content of ice creams, as the UK is set to have another warm weekend - with temperatures expected to hit 18°C.

item.title: Anthrax, animal attacks, and sexual disorders, why some Brits needed medical help in lockdown
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: MailOnline has analysed the latest latest data on NHS patient admissions, appointments and attendances in England from April 1, 2020, to March 31, 2021.

item.title: Parents of 'miracle' conjoined twins - say pair 'constantly hug each other'
item.description: Proud parents Hannah and Dan Bateson from Norhern Ireland, has described their newborn twins conjoined twins Annabelle and Isabelle as 'miracles' who constantly hug each other.

item.title: YouTube is profiting from bogus STI cure videos
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: One video - advocated chewing garlic cloves three times a day to treat the infections, claiming the veg 'will clean you from the tip of your mouth to the anus'.

item.title: Wall Street darling Cassava Sciences is under fire as scientists question trial irregularities
item.description: Cassava Sciences was one of the fastest growing companies in the world last year after promising trials for its Alzheimer's drug. Now, experts are accusing it of potentially manipulating data.

item.title: Should heading be banned from women's football? Study claims they have weaker necks than men
item.description: Researchers from the University of Otago in Dunedin, New Zealand, conducted a review of 25 major studies looking into why women suffer more concussion than men in football.

item.title: HRT crisis is leaving many women suffering sleepless nights as pharmacies start to run out, MP says
item.description: Caroline Nokes, 49, chairman of the Women and Equalities Committee, raised the issue of pharmacies in her constituency 'completely' running out of supplies of HRT.

item.title: World's longest known Covid infection went on for 505 DAYS, scientists reveal
item.description: Covid can infect immunocompromised patients for over 500 days a British study of nine patients has shown with scientists warning extended infections could lead to new variants.

item.title: Woman, 23, who struggled with mood swings for SIX YEARS is diagnosed with brain condition
item.description: Chloe Kral, 23, started suffering mood swings and problems balancing back in 2016. But it was only when she was taken to ER in California that doctors diagnosed her brain condition.

item.title: Britain's decision to space Covid vaccines by 12 weeks was right
item.description: British Government researchers found having a dosage interval of more than 10 weeks can generate nine times more antibodies than having them less than four weeks apart.

item.title: Intermittent fasting will NOT help you lose weight faster, scientists claim
item.description: Restricting eating to six to eight hours a day does not lead to more rapid weight loss, scientists have found. Dr Ethan Weiss, from California University said there was 'no benefit to eating in a narrow window.'

item.title: US is recording more days of 'unhealthy' or 'hazardous' air quality than ever before
item.description: The number of days that Americans suffered from dangerous levels of air pollution reached record levels from 2017 to 2020, a report finds.

item.title: Cancer breakthrough as scientists find a 'treasure trove' of genetic clues
item.description: In the biggest study of its kind, researchers at Cambridge University Hospitals looked at the genomes of more than 12,000 people with cancer in England.

item.title: Britons have suffered from WORMS since the Bronze Age
item.description: Oxford researchers analysed ancient skeletons in an effort to establish the size and scale of parasitic worm infections in the UK over the course of history.

item.title: Former Health Secretary Hancock reveals he is writing a BOOK about his handling of the pandemic
item.description: Britons took to Twitter to suggest titles for Health Secretary Matt Hancock's book, including 'The adulterer's guide to social distancing' and 'Saving lives, s***ging wives'.

item.title: Teenager, 19, who snapped his shin in freak sledging accident learns to walk again
item.description: Ben Thompson, 19, smashed into a metal pole while sliding down a hill on a plastic sledge in Burton-Upon-Trent, Staffordshire. Doctors told him he may never be able to walk again.

item.title: Maine CDC reports death of man from rare incurable Powassan brain virus contracted from tick bite
item.description: A man in Maine has died from the rare Powassan virus - which he is believed to have contracted from the tick bite. Officials warn residents and visitors to be weary of ticks this season.

item.title: Disposable coffee cups shed TRILLIONS of microscopic plastic particles into your drink
item.description: Researchers at the National Institute of Standards and Technology analysed single-use hot beverage cups coated with a soft flexible plastic film often used as a waterproof liner.

item.title: People who suffer from diabetes AND a cognitive impairment are at increased risk of heart disease
item.description: Researchers led by Tel Aviv University, Israel, said the risk could be higher because patients were forgetting to take their medication. But the study was observational.

item.title: Florida health care clinics and pharmacies accused of stealing MILLIONS worth of HIV meds
item.description: Pharma giant Gilead alleges that it was the victim of a widespread fraud scheme in Florida that cost in tens of millions of dollars.

item.title: Top Chinese scientist is censored by Beijing after slamming Zero Covid strategy
item.description: Dr Zhong Nanshan, former president of the Chinese Medical Association, said China has to move away from lockdown cycles in order to 'normalise' the economy and society.
item.media:credit: Visual China Group via Getty Ima

item.title: Mississippi is the nation's chlamydia and gonorrhea capital, figures reveal
item.description: Mississippi's outbreaks were blamed on a stigma around getting tested for the diseases and admitting to the infection. In Nevada, the rise of its hook-up culture was said to have sparked the rise.

item.title: Just one in FIFTY people who were quarantined in hotels during pandemic tested positive for Covid
item.description: The National Audit Office found only one in 50 quarantined guests tested positive for Covid while in self-isolation at a designated hotel between February and December 2021.

item.title: Forget brushing your teeth... KISSING is just as good, claims dentist
item.description: People should add a four minute smooch into their oral health routine to increase salvia production and wash away bad bacteria stuck on their teeth an orthodontist has claimed.

item.title: Covid UK: DofH officials admit £461m wasted on useless PPE 'could have paid for a new hospital'
item.description: Jonathan Marron, a top civil servant at the UK Department of Health, admitted £461m of taxpayer cash was blown on PPE that was unfit for use.

item.title: Pensioners are the most generous generation as 'love hormone' makes them more giving, study shows
item.description: Scrooge may be one of the world's best known old misers but it seems that Charles Dickens' character is far from typical (stock image).

item.title: Experts describe America's nursing home system as 'ineffective, inefficient, fragmented'
item.description: A Washington D.C.-based think tank is issuing grave warnings about the current state of U.S. nursing homes. NASEM describes the situation as 'ineffective, inefficient, fragmented, and unsustainable'.

item.title: Antidepressants DON'T make people any happier, major study claims
item.description: Researchers at King Saud University, Saudi Arabia, found taking antidepressants does not have any long-term benefit for psychological well-being compared to not having the medication.

item.title: Heart attacks in Democrat-voting southern California jumped 53% following in the 2020 US Election
item.description: Researchers at Kaiser Permanente - one of the state's health systems - compared admissions over five days a fortnight before ballots were cast to the period immediately afterwards.

item.title: Warning over cannabis 'edibles' as doctors urge parents to store them far away from children
item.description: Researchers at New York University found 22 products that could be mistaken for regular snacks at 'first glance'. Parents were urged to keep them out of reach of children.

item.title: Tracey Emin shares graphic photo of her stoma to raise awareness after battle with bladder cancer
item.description: WARNING GRAPHIC CONTENT: The 58-year-old Brit underwent a series of major operations in 2020 to remove her bladder after being diagnosed during lockdown.

item.title: Britain's daily Covid cases plunge by another third as hospitalisations and deaths fall again
item.description: UK Health Security Agency bosses today posted another 26,147 positive swabs over the last 24 hours - the lowest figure in two months and a quarter fewer than last week.

item.title: Woman, 22, accused of being 'drunk' at work discovers she actually has EPILEPSY
item.description: Annie Newcomen, a speech therapist from Liverpool, had been suffering from 'episodes' that would cause sudden brain fog and memory loss in the lead up to her diagnosis in March.

item.title: Omicron sub-variant causing havoc in the US is already in Britain
item.description: Little is known about the new version of the virus, though it is believed to have an up to 27 per cent growth advantage over BA.2, the Omicron subvariant currently dominant in the UK.

item.title: Using smartphone for an hour less a day makes you less anxious and more satisfied, study says
item.description: Past studies have shown that smartphone use is linked to obesity, neck pain and addictive behaviour, so Ruhr-Universität Bochum experts set out to establish just how much use is too much.

item.title: Mother, 23, who feared she was infertile gave birth to five babies
item.description: Hannah Merton, 23, from Akron, Ohio, turned to fertility mediation after struggling to conceive for six months and to her shock fell pregnant with five babies in October 2019.

item.title: Suicide rates twice as high among patients with terminal cancers, heart disease and COPD
item.description: A first of its kind analysis by the Office for National Statistics found the risk spikes sharply after a devastating diagnosis but slows over time. The report looked at 17,000 suicides in England.

item.title: Eating a Mediterranean diet during pregnancy may cut odds of getting pre-eclampsia by 20%
item.description: Kim Kardashian and Beyonce both suffered from the condition, which is thought to affect around 5 per cent of pregnancies. The study was carried out at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore.

item.title: Women feel more 'overwhelmed, stressed and frustrated' at work
item.description: Yale University-led experts found that, compared to men, women reported feeling more overwhelmed, stressed, frustrated, tense, and discouraged, and less respected and confident.

item.title: How you can fight back when you're at risk of dementia
item.description: Guy Eaton, 55, a company director, lives in Hackney, London. He says: 'I've always been in good health but last September I had a fall from my bike - I fell backwards after slamming on the brakes'.

item.title: Lone wolf terrorists could engineer a pandemic worse than Covid, says ex president of Royal Society
item.description: Lord Rees of Ludlow, the ex-president of the Royal Society, said the potential for individuals to manipulate viruses to be more deadly keeps him 'awake at night'.

item.title: Half of small GP surgeries have shut in a decade with patients sent to 'soulless' alternatives
item.description: Half of England's small GP surgeries have closed in less than a decade, new figures show. More and more patients are forced to travel to 'soulless' mega practices with less continuity of care.

item.title: IVF clinics pushing expensive add-ons on would-be mothers
item.description: Last year the Competition and Markets Authority issued guidance for fertility clinics to ensure they don't mis-sell add-on treatments, which can add up to £2,500 to the cost of each IVF attempt.

item.title: Researchers make breakthrough in fight against HIV using CRISPR gene editing
item.description: Researchers at Northwestern Universities have uncovered genes associated with the process of HIV infecting and replicating cells

item.title: J&J DROPS its Covid vaccine from sales forecasts
item.description: The New Jersey-based company today shaved $1billion off its estimated sales from all products. At the start of the year they predicted the vaccine would bring in $3.5bn, or 46 per cent up on last year

item.title: Man, 60, gets dental drill bit lodged in lungs for FOUR DAYS after inhaling it
item.description: Tom Jozsi, 60, was getting a tooth filling at a surgery in Illinois when he suddenly felt 'a cough'. Doctors removed the dental drill bit using a device normally reserved for cancer patients.

item.title: Experts warn Tucker Carlson-promoted 'testicle tanning' is USELESS
item.description: Experts warn that the practice of 'testicle tanning' will do little to boost T levels or raise sperm counts.
item.media:credit: Fox News / Indiana University Health / Johns Hopkins Medicine

item.title: How rife is Covid in YOUR holiday destination? Rates 1,000 TIMES higher in France than Morocco
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: France has recorded 1,746 cases per million people over the last week, while the figures for Morocco, Tunisia and Turkey are up to 1,300 times fewer.

item.title: CDC adds ANOTHER version of the Omicron variant to its weekly Covid tracker
item.description: The CDC is now recognizing the BA.2.12.2 sub-lineage of the 'stealth' variant, which is in itself a sub-variant of Omicron, as its own version of the virus.

item.title: Just how bad for you is YOUR favourite milkshake? Popular shakes can be packed with 1,200 calories
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Anti-obesity campaigners today called our findings 'outrageous' and argued it was 'about time these food chains acted more responsibly'.

item.title: American serial sperm donor travels across the UK to impregnate as many women as possible
item.description: Kyle Gordy, 30, from LA, California, has already made six donations to women in the UK and Europe on what he's dubbed his 'donation tours'.
item.media:credit: Johnathan Celis / CATERS NEWS / Kyle Gordy / CATERS NEWS

item.title: Scientists develop an app that can detect whether you have Covid-19 with 92 per cent accuracy
item.description: The app, called ResApp, uses machine learning to analyse the sounds of your cough. During testing, the app was found to correctly detect COVID-19 in 92 per cent of people with the infection.

item.title: Covid UK: Calls for FREE or cheap Covid lateral flow tests to get Britain back to work
item.description: The British Chambers of Commerce says up to 75% of companies reported at least one staff member off sick with coronavirus in the last four weeks amid a recent surge in Covid cases.

item.title: Brazilian boy born with two penises in one-in-5million defect
item.description: A two-year-old Brazilian boy born with two penises has had the larger of his pair chopped off after medics found only the the smaller one was working correctly allowing him to pass urine.

item.title: Ex-football star PAUL FERRIS: The brutal truth about prostate cancer every man must read
item.description: PAUL FERRIS: Two hospitals in one day. Heart disease and cancer. Two of the biggest causes of death in the Western world and I was at that moment sure I would be a sufferer of both.

item.title: DR MARTIN SCURR answers your health questions
item.description: DR MARTIN SCURR: I am not familiar with the term 'splinter' headache, although I suspect it is what is known medically as a primary stabbing headache, often also called ice-pick headaches.

item.title: Jab for lame horses may ease pain of knee arthritis
item.description: Tests on people with arthritis showed most got pain relief within days or weeks of the jab, and that the benefits lasted at least a year.

item.title: We ask the experts whether freezing it or eating a fresh loaf is better for your health
item.description: Whether you prefer your toast golden or dark, your loaf frozen or fresh, it changes the structure of the bread - and the impact it can have on your health.

item.title: Type 2 diabetics can add over a DECADE to their lives, study says
item.description: Researchers at the University of Florida monitored 421 adults with the condition who were about 65 years old. They found patients of a healthy weight lived a decade longer.

item.title: Inflatable boots that can relieve swollen feet
item.description: A staggering 60 per cent of us suffer from foot problems, ranging from athlete's foot to bunions, according to recent figures from the Society of Chiropodists and Podiatrists.

item.title: Scientists say the way you talk could help diagnose a range of conditions
item.description: In the latest breakthrough, doctors have used short recordings of speech to assess if people are at risk of a heart attack caused by clogged arteries.

item.title: Global deaths from antibiotic-resistant 'super bugs' have surged seven-fold in half a decade
item.description: Dr Christopher Murray, from Washington University, estimated 5million people are dying from the infections every year. This was up from 700,000 estimated five years beforehand.

item.title: NHS beds crisis as vacancy level hits lowest since Covid pandemic started
item.description: Data shows 14,000 beds are occupied by Covid-infected patients, even though half aren't actually unwell with the virus itself and have incidentally tested positive while being treated for other reasons.

item.title: Cancer vaccine using same tech as Covid jabs could be a 'game-changer', scientists say
item.description: Zachary Hartman, an assistant professor in immunology at Duke University, North Carolina, said: 'If we can roll this out in the clinic for cancer, we think it could be a game-changer.'

item.title: Pharma giant J&J pays out $99 million settlement to West Virginia over opioid crisis
item.description: J&J paid out nearly $100 million to the state of West Virginia to settles a lawsuit over the company's role in the opioid epidemic. West Virginia has suffered the worst of America's growing drug problem.

item.title: Travel nurse arrested after 'tampering with and removing vials' of powerful painkiller
item.description: Jacqueline Brewster, 52, from Kentucky was accused of opening and re-sealing vials at a hospital in Tennessee. But she was then re-employed in West Virginia and again faced the accusations.
item.media:credit: Johnson City Medical Center / Raleigh General Hospital / Twitter

item.title: Less than HALF of people in parts of England are vaccinated... how many are jabbed in YOUR area?
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Vaccination data for England shows Harehills South, a neighbourhood of Leeds famed for crime and anti-social behaviour, has the lowest uptake rate.

item.title: Global COVID-19 death toll may be TRIPLE officially reported numbers
item.description: An IHME report finds that the global death toll from the COVID-19 pandemic may be triple the officially reported figures.

item.title: Global daily Covid deaths are now at their LOWEST point since pandemic took off
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: The seven-day average number of Covid fatalities worldwide was 2,813 on Sunday, the lowest since March 28, 2020, when it was 2,735.

item.title: Is your mother-in-law a nightmare? It's NOT your fault
item.description: US researchers, who quizzed 100 people on their relationships with their family and in-laws, found men and women had poorer relationships with their mother-in-law.

item.title: Glioblastoma: Most deadly form of brain cancer that kills more than half of patients within a year
item.description: Brain cancer is rare, being detected in about one in 15,000 Americans every year official figures show. But at a high school in New Jersey more than 100 students have been found to have the condition.

item.title: Women living in England's poorest neighbourhoods die YOUNGER 'devastating' analysis reveals
item.description: Research by the Health Foundation shows women living in the most deprived areas on England had an average life expectancy of 78 years and eight months at birth in 2017 to 2019.

item.title: Women up to age of 50 are freezing their eggs
item.description: After actress Sienna Miller revealed she has frozen her eggs at 40, it has emerged that British women are doing so right up to their 50th birthdays.

item.title: Midwives urged to avoid using proper words for anatomy to avoid upsetting trans patients
item.description: Midwives have been advised not to say 'vagina' or 'breast milk' under new guidelines issued by the Brighton and Sussex University Hospitals NHS Trust. The move is said to support trans patients.

item.title: Patients hit out after doctor dismissed concerns about difficulties of face-to-face GP appointments
item.description: Professor Dame Clare Gerada, President of the Royal College of GPs, made the remark after describing the shift to online consultations as the most positive development of the pandemic.

item.title: More than 11,000 helpers who signed on to deliver Covid shots have since taken up health service job
item.description: When make-up artist Chloe Radley lost most of her customers during the pandemic she decided to turn her steady hand to something else: becoming a vaccine volunteer.

item.title: Tensing your muscles can be key to a good afternoon nap by helping you drift into deeper sleep
item.description: People who intentionally tensed and then relaxed their large muscle groups before they drifted off had 125 per cent more deep sleep compared to people who listened to relaxing music, researchers found.

item.title: Six-hour stroll is needed to burn off just one Easter egg, expert says
item.description: Those special chocolate treats people permit themselves at Easter might take a lot longer to burn off than people realise, according to experts at Loughborough University.

item.title: DR ELLIE CANNON: I've been taking a laxative for two years... could it harm me?
item.description: DR ELLIE CANNON: Constipation is a common problem, but laxatives are usually not recommended long-term because they can affect the balance of fluid in the body.

item.title: Are lingering Covid symptoms like shortness of breath and chest pain linked to heart disease?
item.description: Researchers found patients with Covid are more likely to suffer from cardiovascular conditions including abnormal heart rhythms, heart muscle inflammation, blood clots and heart attacks.

item.title: HEALTH NOTES: Half of men are against a male contraceptive
item.description: In the new study of 1,000 men by Lloyds Pharmacy, only 42 per cent of men said they would be happy to do take a male contraceptive.

item.title: Parkinson's patients 'to be given high-tech £175 smartwatch on the NHS'
item.description: Parkinson's patients could be given a £175 high-tech smart watch that lets doctors remotely monitor their movement and sleeping patterns - key indicators of complications from the brain disease.

item.title: Expert warns there is 'no health benefit' to ultra-dark chocolate Easter eggs
item.description: Professor Duane Mellor at Aston University says most of the studies that tout the miracle health claims of eating ultra-dark chocolate 'can't be applied to the real world'.

item.title: Experts hail new double-drug therapy that can boost the survival of lung cancer patients
item.description: One patient who has first-hand experience of the remarkable effects of nivolumab is grandmother-of-three Norma McAra, 70, from Arbroath, pictured above.

item.title: Drug that 'adds years' onto the lives of bladder cancer sufferers will be offered on the NHS
item.description: Bladder cancer sufferer Andrew Younger, 72, joined a trial for avelumab after being told that tumours had spread to his lung, neck and stomach, and that he might not live to see the next year.

item.title: Experts say GPs are risking another NHS scandal by not prescribing new mothers anti-depressants
item.description: Growing numbers of health professionals say the dangers of new mothers using anti-depressants are minimal and are being overstated by over-cautious GPs and other healthcare professionals.

item.title: Britain can blame WFH for a rise in botched boob jobs
item.description: Reality TV star Katie Price last summer travelled to Turkey for liposuction, when the Government had the country on the 'red list'. It meant that people should not visit 'except in extreme circumstances'.

item.title: US is hit by mysterious spate of severe hepatitis cases in children
item.description: Nine children - all under six years old - have been struck down with severe cases of the liver condition since October. At least one led to acute liver failure. Alabama officials say there is no link between cases.

item.title: Only 9% of Americans can properly read a nutrition label
item.description: Americans fail to properly read nutrition labels and make correct, healthy, purchasing decisions in the grocery store, a new study finds.
item.media:credit: Getty Images / Getty Images/Tetra images RF

item.title: Almost every child in America has tobacco on their hands, study finds
item.description: Researchers at San Diego State University, California, swabbed fingers of 500 children around six years old. Three-fifths were from non-smoking homes, but 96 per cent of all kids had nicotine on their hands.

item.title: What milk should I use?
item.description: Experts recommend that Americans use milk products that fill gaps in their personal nutritional profile.
item.media:credit: Getty Images / NYU Langone / Shutterstock / Kristi Blokhin / Mayo Clinic

item.title: DR MICHAEL MOSLEY: Why going DOWN stairs is better for you than going up!
item.description: DR MICHAEL MOSLEY: We all know the benefits of doing exercise, both for the brain and the body, but it can be difficult to motivate yourself to get going.

item.title: HALF of nurses in the US say they have experienced a spike in workplace violence over the past year
item.description: In its bi-annual survey, National Nurses United found more than 48 per cent of nurses said they had experienced a small or significant spike in workplace violence.

item.title: Covid cases now INCREASING in 32 US states as virus makes resurgence in the Northeast
item.description: Covid cases have jumped nationwide to over 40,000 per day for the first time since early March, but deaths remain low, according to official figures.

item.title: Use our search tool to see how YOUR NHS trust is performing
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Fewer than half of patients attending England's worst-performing A&E can expect to be seen and sent home within four hours.

item.title: Newcastle is named the worst city in EUROPE for nitrogen dioxide pollution in March
item.description: Cleantech firm Airly uses sensors and AI-driven algorithms to study nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and particulate matter (PM10) elements of air pollution across European cities.

item.title: The injuries that hundreds of Britons claim to have suffered while taking Covid tests
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Dozens of people in the UK say they've fainted or choked while swabbing, while others have complained about nose bleeds and hot flashes.

item.title: Multiple sclerosis breakthrough as scientists reverse condition with immune cell transplant
item.description: Immune cells against glandular fever may hold the key to treating multiple sclerosis. The T-cell therapy has been created by US firm Atara Biotherapeutics, based in San Francisco, California.

item.title: Doctor urges women to stop swapping HRT medication with strangers
item.description: Manufacturers have warned of shortages of some hormone replacement therapy drugs (HRT) in England, including popular gels, patches and tablets.

item.title: Suicide rates FELL in England and Wales in 2020 despite Covid lockdown, ONS data shows
item.description: Figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) found the overall suicide rate was 9.8 deaths per 100,000 people from April to December 2020. This was significantly lower than in 2019.

item.title: Why humans live to 80 while giraffes die at 24: Animals with slower genetic mutations live longer
item.description: Researchers from the Wellcome Sanger Institute compared the genomes of 16 species and found animals with a slower rate of genetic changes have longer lifespans.

item.title: One-in-four American adults are living with a potentially LIFE THREATENING liver disorder
item.description: American Heart Association today called for improvements in diagnosis methods and awareness of the condition. Its chair said the disease is often 'hidden or missed'.

item.title: Asthma and Allergy Foundation criticize Biden administration's plan to lift ban on E15 fuel
item.description: The Biden administration is lifting a summertime ban on E15 fuel this year in an effort to combat surging gas prices. Experts warn the move can harm people suffering from respiratory issues.
item.media:credit: Getty Images / AFP via Getty Images

item.title: Johnson & Johnson bankruptcy will NOT protect it against asbestos lawsuit from former employees
item.description: Johnson & Johnson will not be able to avoid facing a class-action lawsuit from employees that allege the company exposed them to asbestos.

item.title: Nearly 600,000 course of Pfizer's Paxlovid are sitting UNUSED in America
item.description: Experts suggest too few doctors are aware of the treatments, leading to them rarely being prescribed. Data shows 580,000 Paxlovid courses are available across the U.S. at present.

item.title: Two NEW sub-variants of the Omicron 'stealth' variant are discovered in NYC as cases jump 60%
item.description: New York health officials have detected two fast rising sub-strains of the BA.2 COVID-19 'stealth' variant, which is itself a sub-variant of Omicron.

item.title: Booster of Pfizer's Covid vaccine in five to 11 year olds sparked 36-fold antibody surge
item.description: Pfizer said the results 'reinforce' offering booster jabs to children in the U.S. to 'maintain' their levels of protection against Covid. But the age group is at a vanishingly low risk from the virus.

item.title: Covid UK: ONS says latest wave HAS peaked as cases and hospitalisations fall, though deaths rise
item.description: UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) bosses logged another 32,608 positive tests over the last 24 hours, down 30.8 per cent in a week.

item.title: NHS waiting list hits ANOTHER high amid Covid-fuelled crisis: 6.18MILLION waiting for routine ops
item.description: NHS England data shows one in nine people in the country are waiting, often in pain, for elective operations such as hip and knee replacements and cataracts surgery.

item.title: UK GP body accused of fuelling NHS staffing crisis with ads for £200k-a-year jobs in Australia
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Campaigners say the Royal College of GPs advertising £200k-a-year jobs in Australia enticing them with sunshine and surfing is helping fuel a UK shortage of doctors.

item.title: Man gets headphone wire stuck in his bladder after shoving it down his penis while masturbating
item.description: The man went to Dr Soetmo General-Academic Hospital in Surabaya complaining of stomach pains when urinating. He told doctors he used the wire three to five times a week.

item.title: Hay fever warning issued as the Met Office predicts high pollen levels over Easter weekend
item.description: The Met Office has revealed that pollen levels are expected to be high across most of England and Wales over the Easter weekend.

item.title: NHS England: GP 'postcode lottery means patient-doctor ratio 70 times higher in some areas
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: MailOnline analysis shows Hastings Old Surgery in East Sussex has nearly 15,500 patients for every full-time GP as of February 28, the latest date official figures go up to.

item.title: Covid UK: ONS testing survey shows ases are falling but 3.7million still infected
item.description: The ONS' 3.7m estimate marks a near 9 per cent fall on the record 4.1m the previous week and puts an end to a five-week spell of growth after Covid restrictions were released in England in February.

item.title: BBC cancer podcast host Deborah James discharged from hospital after sepsis battle
item.description: BBC podcast host Deborah James, who has incurable bowel cancer, has revealed she has been discharged from the Royal Marsden Hospital, in London, after more than a month.

item.title: Make your own way to hospital... to save the NHS! Paramedic says crisis needs 'emergency measures'
item.description: Kristin Houlgate, who works for South Western Ambulance Service, said she is not confident the NHS ambulance service can 'provide a safe level of service to the British public'.

item.title: Valneva's Covid vaccine gets approved for use in UK but No10 already cancelled £1.2billion contract
item.description: The UK's medicines watchdog, which is the first in the world to approve the two-dose vaccine, said it is safe and effective in 18 to 50-year-olds.

item.title: 60 patients in England have been waiting more than three years for surgery
item.description: Data from 60 hospitals in England show at least 58 patients have been waiting in 'soul destroying' pain for routine operations for more than three years.

item.title: Israeli study says extra Covid booster cuts risk of dying by another 75%
item.description: Israeli and US scientists say a new analysis shows fourth Covid jabs offer better protection than three against the virus but UK experts say the gains are minor as the booster is already so effective.

item.title: A record 105,000 Americans died of a drug overdose from October 2020 to 2021
item.description: The CDC reports that a record of 105,000 Americans died of a drug overdose between the last two Octobers, a devastating milestone caused mostly by fentanyl and other opioids.

item.title: Intense exercise can help a person develop a healthier diet
item.description: Researchers from Washington State University found that mice that took part rigorous exercise were less likely to show cravings for fatty foods.

item.title: Recipients of Paxlovid report symptoms returning and even testing positive for the virus again
item.description: Some recipients of Paxlovid, an antiviral pill developed by Pfizer, are reporting Covid symptoms returning after finishing their course of the drug.

item.title: Los Angeles REINSTATES masks on transit despite federal court striking down federal rules
item.description: Philadelphia will now only 'strongly encourage' people to wear masks in public spaces including schools, restaurants and public buildings. Los Angeles yesterday imposed face masks.

item.title: American children are more likely to die by gun violence than any other cause
item.description: Deaths from gun violence are now the leading killer of American children, a research report finds. Researchers can not explain the root cause for the concerning spike in gun violence.

item.title: New Yorkers report confusion and frustration over the Big Apple KEEPING mask orders
item.description: New Yorkers report feelings of frustration and confusion over the city's existing transportation mask mandate.

item.title: 'Treasure trove' of DNA from tumors provides British researchers with hope for new cancer cures
item.description: Researchers in the U.K. studied 12,000 people with cancer and identified 58 new patterns in their DNA - a significant increase on the 51 patterns previously known.

item.title: These £22 slippers with arch support are 'perfect for people with plantar fasciitis'
item.description: Proving that shoes for plantar fasciitis can be stylish, the COFACE Women Sliders Faux Fur Orthotic Slippers are highly recommended by more than 3,600 shoppers, and they cost under £22.

item.title: Lifting of federal Covid mask orders leaves Americans confused
item.description: This week, a federal court struck down the CDC's Covid mask orders that applied to all forms of public transportation.

item.title: This £30 ergonomic seat cushion provides immediate support and pain relief when WFH
item.description: Designed to relieve pressure from the tailbone and bottom, Amazon shoppers swear by the Everlasting Comfort Seat Cushion to create a comfortable working environment and it's on...

item.title: Bay Area health systems face nurses strikes in a week
item.description: Nurses walked out of 15 hospitals run by Sutter Health on Monday, in cities including San Francisco. They will also walk out of two hospitals run by Stanford Health Care on Monday.

item.title: Does this £200 jar of Lyma supplements work better than High Street rivals?
item.description: The Mail on Sunday's Eve Simmons asked the experts to provide an honest assessment of the lofty claims made by some of the most expensive supplement brands in Britain.

item.title: FDA to gain power to regulate synthetic nicotine starting April 14
item.description: The FDA will be able to regulate synthetic nicotine products starting April 14, opening the door for banning flavored nicotine products for good.

item.title: Man, 51, suffers amputation of all five fingers on his right hand
item.description: WARNING, GRAPHIC CONTENT: The 51-year-old was rushed to hospital in 'severe' pain about an hour after administering the three pills into his right forearm in Brasilia, the capital of Brazil.

item.title: US cases of the STDs gonorrhea and syphilis surged to a 30-year high in 2020
item.description: CDC officials warned the 'unrelenting momentum' of the nation's STD epidemic continued throughout the first year of the Covid pandemic. This may be due to less testing, leading to accidental transmission.

item.title: Covid-fighting nasal spray removes claim it offers up to eight-hour protection against virus
item.description: Bottles of CofixRX - sold in 800 US pharmacies for $24.95 each - had made the bold suggestion when they first went on sale. But the allegation has now been quietly removed.

item.title: US records a record 106,000 drug overdose deaths from November 2020 to 2021
item.description: The U.S. recorded a new high of 106,000 drug overdose deaths from November 2020 to 2021, the sixth straight month with a new record. Fentanyl is most responsible.

item.title: 2021 was the deadliest year in US history - mainly fueled by COVID-19
item.description: The CDC reports that 2021 was the deadliest year in US history, with 3.5 million deaths being recorded last year. The COVID-19 pandemic fueled the rise, with more than 400,000 deaths.

item.title: Flu failed to bounce back this winter because of COVID-19, scientists suggest
item.description: Fears of hospitals being rocked by a 'twindemic' - when Covid and flu strike at the same time - were not realised this winter. Scientists suggest this could be repeated for years to come.

item.title: TikTok like a 'candy store' of 'immediate pleasure' for child users, says Oxford University ethicist
item.description: James Williams, who was also an advertising strategist at Google, said: 'It's like we've made kids live in a candy store and then we tell them to ignore all that candy and eat a plate of vegetables.'

item.title: Learning a second language may help stave off dementia
item.description: Russian and UK researchers say speaking another language can help delay dementia by up to seven years and that the more fluent you are the sharper your mind as you age.

item.title: Toddler's white 'glow' in his eye turned out to be deadly tumour
item.description: Leonnie Ord, from Tyne and Wear, first noticed a glow over her one-year-old son Cillian Coyles' left pupil last summer but dismissed it as the light reflecting in his eye.

item.title: Swiss man, 20, was left in intensive care after suffering rare lung injury from masturbating
item.description: The Swiss patient, who has not been named, went to hospital after experiencing sudden chest pain and struggling to breathe while pleasuring himself in bed.

item.title: Mothers at 'unsafe' maternity unit say they were left in agony for HOURS
item.description: Three British mothers have detailed horrific experiences of poor maternity care at a Sheffield trust, with one saying she was left in agony begging for help for eight hours.

item.title: Study suggests overweight mothers are more likely to have children with asthma
item.description: Some experts have suggested this may be because overweight women produce more of a hormone called leptin, which may make the airways of their unborn child more sensitive.

item.title: Brazilian man, 54, shoves a DUMBBELL in his rectum for 'sexual pleasure'
item.description: Brazilian medics had to pull a 20cm metal dumbbell out of 54-year-old man's rectum after surgical tools failed to remove the stuck object which he had inserted for sexual pleasure.

item.title: Meningitis vaccine can protect against super gonnorhoea, Lancet studies claim
item.description: Three studies, carried out by experts in the UK, US and Australia, suggest the meningitis jab could reduce cases of gonorrhoea, the UK's second most common STI.

item.title: Osteopathy: Study claims the controversial alternative medicine can help musculoskeletal disorders
item.description: Italian osteopaths claimed there is 'promising evidence' osteopathy can help relieve back and neck, pain. Experts told MailOnline most of the studies in the review have limited reliability.
